issues.title: Transpiler bug when importing modules named after the same folder
issues.body:
consider a module `/foo&bar.n4js` and a module `/foo.n4js` which export some variable:

foo.n4js
```js
export public const c = 5;

```
/foo/bar.n4js
```js
import {c} from "foo"
console.log(c)
```

the transpiled output is
```js
// Generated by N4JS transpiler; for copyright see original N4JS source file.

import 'n4js-runtime'
import {c} from './'

console.log(c);
//# sourceMappingURL=bar.map
```
which is wrong it should

```js
// Generated by N4JS transpiler; for copyright see original N4JS source file.

import 'n4js-runtime'
import {c} from '../foo'

console.log(c);
//# sourceMappingURL=bar.map
```

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-1780: Transpiler bug when importing modules named after the same folder (#1781)

* fix bug in module specifier computation

* add 2 tests

issues.title: Build progress logging is laggy
issues.body:
The logging of the build progress is working in principle, but sometimes a particular build log message shows up in VSCode significantly later than it was sent by the LSP server.

This seems to happen only when starting the LSP server from within the VSCode extension, not when using a server started from a host development Eclipse instance.

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-1776: Build progress logging is laggy (#1778)

* Revert "GH-1751/GH-1757: As a developer I want a super simple, preliminary progress indicator for the incremental build (#1758)"

This reverts commit 5438bc44f06b2e439e4044068997443bfa8da274.

* additional build progress logging in two places

issues.title: LSP builder not using Xtext API for handling cancellation exceptions
issues.body:
Some methods in the LSP builder catch `java.util.concurrent.CancellationException` but do not catch `org.eclipse.core.runtime.OperationCanceledException` which is thrown by our code, resulting in behavior for "unknown exception" to be executed in case of cancellation.

Probably the Xtext API for handling cancellation should be used instead, e.g. something like `operationCanceledManager.isOperationCanceledException(t)`.

This applies to methods:
```
org.eclipse.n4js.ide.xtext.server.XBuildManager.doIncrementalBuild(boolean, CancelIndicator)
org.eclipse.n4js.ide.xtext.server.build.XStatefulIncrementalBuilder.launch()
```
(check code for more cases).

Seems to be done properly in:
```
org.eclipse.n4js.ide.xtext.server.build.XIncrementalBuilder.build(XBuildRequest, IResourceClusteringPolicy)
```

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-1749: LSP builder not using Xtext API for handling cancellation exceptions (#1752)

* use OperationCanceledManager to handle cancel-related exceptions

* disable parallel execution of read-requests

* review feedback

issues.title: Some tests in bundle org.eclipse.n4js.ide.tests are not executed on Jenkins
issues.body:
Some of the tests in bundle `org.eclipse.n4js.ide.tests` are not executed on Jenkins.

For one of those tests there exists another ticket (see #1392) and that test is not working properly anyway. Fixing that test is not part of this ticket (just set it on ignore), it must be investigated why that test and others are not running on Jenkins and that must be fixed.

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-1734: Some tests in bundle org.eclipse.n4js.ide.tests are not executed on Jenkins (#1744)

* temporary: disable all test bundles except the IDE tests bundle

* add xtend compilation to pom of org.eclipse.n4js.ide.tests

* GH-1734: Be robust against absent project

* Stabilize tests for XRequestManager

* GH-1734: Run test only once

* GH-1734: Use ConcurrentHashMap and atomic operations in WorkspaceMngr

The openDocuments map is read from multiple threads. Therefore we need
to use a concurrent data structure to ensure consistency.

* GH-1734: Mark N4JSLanguageServer as Guice Singleton

* GH-1734: Queueig of dirty and changed files may not be cancellable

* GH-1734: Added API to XRequestManager that allows to await all requests

Using a dummy read request is not sufficient since multiple readers may
run concurrently and the dummy may be faster than other readers.
A write request would cancel the pending readers which is not desired
either.

* GH-1734: Allow to wait for the server to shutdown

Improved teardown logic in AbstractIdeTest to discard previously created
thread pools and wait for the server to shutdown orderly.

* GH-1734: Disable assertion, added Fixme

* Revert "temporary: disable all test bundles except the IDE tests bundle"

This reverts commit dd6e31008107e75021d9061c50fab5fd0dc6c969.

* remove synchronized(this) + log an error

* set a test on ignore that is not fixed yet

Co-authored-by: Sebastian Zarnekow <sebastian.zarnekow@gmail.com>

GH-1734: Some tests in bundle org.eclipse.n4js.ide.tests are not executed on Jenkins (#1760)

* fix bug in finalization logic of post processing

issues.title: Project dependency not recognised when located inside a project node_modules folder of a yarn project only
issues.body: Given there is a project `P` in a yarn workspace setup (i.e. in the workspaces project) and `P` has a nested node_modules folder which contains a dependency `D` of `P`.  Then `D` is not recognised iff it is only inside the node_modules folder `P` (that means it must not be located in the node_modules folder of the yarn workspace project.)

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-1716: Project dependency not recognised when located inside a project node_modules folder of a yarn project only (#1717)

* fix bug

* fix validation

* add reviewers feedback

* add reviewers feedback

issues.title: n4jsc in n4js-cli returning exit code 0 even in case of compile errors
issues.body:
The command line tool `n4jsc` contained in npm package `n4js-cli` returns an exit code of 0 even though there are compile errors in the N4JS source code being compiled.

To reproduce:

1. create a new, empty N4JS project.
2. add dev-dependency `n4js-cli` to package.json:
   ```json
   "devDependencies": {
   	"n4js-cli": "0.19.6"
   },
   ```
3. add a file to the source folder with a compile error:
   ```javascript
   const c: string = 42;
   ```
4. in bash, go to the root folder of the newly created N4JS project and run
   ```
   $ ./node_modules/.bin/n4jsc compile .
   ```
   which will report the compile error. When printing the exit code with
   ```
   $ echo $?
   ```
   we get `0` instead of the expected non-zero value.

issues.title: n4js-cli does not always detect correct version of installed JRE
issues.body:
At the moment, n4js-cli uses the return string of the call to `java -version` to figure out the JRE version. This is error prone since these returns string do not share a common format.

Goal here is to improve the logic to always return the correct JRE version.

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-1661: n4js-cli does not always detect correct version of installed JRE (#1662)

* improve java version detection

* use feature segment only

* clean ups

* add PrintJavaVersion.java to bin; improve logs

* adjust extension to changes in n4js-cli

* move PrintJavaVersion to resources dir

issues.title: Fix n4js-cli to identify Java version more robust
issues.body:
the current implementation to identify the installed Java version is too specific and does not recognise some print outs of Java distributions. Support at least the following:

```
openjdk version "11.0.6" 2020-01-14
java version "11.0.4" 2019-07-16 LTS
```

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-1642: Fix n4js-cli to identify Java version more robust (#1643)

* improve regex to identify Java version, add groups prop

* improve regex

issues.title: N4JS cannot be used in web pages with CSP / `unsafe-eval`
issues.body:
The N4JS runtime classes currently use eval to determine `globalThis`, see https://github.com/eclipse/n4js/blob/master/n4js-libs/packages/n4js-runtime/src/n4js/N4BuiltInTypes.n4js#L301

which causes the `unsafe-eval` violation.

I suggest to just use `globalThis` as is, since it's reasonably supported (node 12, recent browsers) and could otherwise be *properly*  shimmed without eval, see https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/globalThis

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-1635: N4JS cannot be used in web pages with CSP / `unsafe-eval` (#1636)

issues.title: Method N4JSProjectName#equals() throwing exception when hovering in package.json
issues.body:
Method `N4JSProjectName#equals()` throws an exception when hyper links are computed in `package.json` files.

To reproduce:

1. create a new N4JS project using the wizard,
2. open the `package.json` file,
3. hold down the command key (cmd) and hover the mouse over the dependency section inside the `package.json` editor.

Will throw:
```
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: Cannot compare to type java.lang.String
	at org.eclipse.n4js.projectModel.names.N4JSProjectName.equals(N4JSProjectName.java:87)
	at com.google.common.base.Objects.equal(Objects.java:52)
	at org.eclipse.n4js.ui.editor.hyperlinking.packagejson.PackageJsonHyperlinkHelperExtension.getProjectDescriptionLocationForName(PackageJsonHyperlinkHelperExtension.java:260)
	at org.eclipse.n4js.ui.editor.hyperlinking.packagejson.PackageJsonHyperlinkHelperExtension.hyperlinkToProjectProperty(PackageJsonHyperlinkHelperExtension.java:224)
	at org.eclipse.n4js.ui.editor.hyperlinking.packagejson.PackageJsonHyperlinkHelperExtension.getUriRegionPair(PackageJsonHyperlinkHelperExtension.java:149)
	at org.eclipse.n4js.ui.editor.hyperlinking.packagejson.PackageJsonHyperlinkHelperExtension.getHyperlinks(PackageJsonHyperlinkHelperExtension.java:81)
	at org.eclipse.n4js.json.ui.editor.hyperlinking.JSONHyperlinkHelperProvider.createHyperlinksByOffset(JSONHyperlinkHelperProvider.java:28)
	at org.eclipse.xtext.ui.editor.hyperlinking.DefaultHyperlinkDetector$1.exec(DefaultHyperlinkDetector.java:51)
	at org.eclipse.xtext.ui.editor.hyperlinking.DefaultHyperlinkDetector$1.exec(DefaultHyperlinkDetector.java:1)
	at org.eclipse.xtext.util.concurrent.IReadAccess.lambda$tryReadOnly$0(IReadAccess.java:56)
	at org.eclipse.xtext.resource.OutdatedStateManager.exec(OutdatedStateManager.java:91)
...
```

Obviously, the implementation of `N4JSProjectName#equals()` is violating the contract of `Object#equals()`. However, this was probably done to find suspicious places in the code where different kinds of project names are confused. So, probably rather `PackageJsonHyperlinkHelperExtension#getProjectDescriptionLocationForName()` should be adjusted.

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-1561: Use resource locator API to load builtin resources (#1576)

The resource locator abstraction allows to load the builtin resources only once for all resource sets that are created. Sharing the resources will reduce the memory consumption and also improve performance.

see #1561
also closes #1553

issues.title: Incorrect shadowing of npm packages in headless builder
issues.body:
When using a yarn workspace with two projects P1 and P2 and both projects depend on two different versions of the same npm package D, then yarn will install one version of D into the node_modules folder located in the yarn workspace root folder and another version of D in a nested node_modules folder located in either P1 and P2.

In this case, the behavior of the N4JS IDE and the N4JS headless builder are different: in the headless case, the version of D in the nested node_modules folder will be compiled and presented to the projects P1 and P2, which is not intended.

The behavior of the headless builder should be changed to match that of the IDE.

issues.title: Invalid static polyfill of built-in type leads to uncaught exception in type system
issues.body:
To reproduce:
```javascript
@@StaticPolyfillModule

@StaticPolyfill
export public class Date extends Date { // polyfill for built-in type Date
	
	public foo() {
		super.hasOwnProperty("dummy");
	}
}
```
Throws exception:
```
java.lang.ClassCastException: org.eclipse.n4js.ts.types.impl.TObjectPrototypeImpl cannot be cast to org.eclipse.n4js.ts.types.TClass
	at org.eclipse.n4js.typesystem.TypeJudgment$TypeJudgmentSwitchForASTNodes.caseSuperLiteral(TypeJudgment.java:611)
	at org.eclipse.n4js.typesystem.TypeJudgment$TypeJudgmentSwitchForASTNodes.caseSuperLiteral(TypeJudgment.java:1)
	at org.eclipse.n4js.n4JS.util.N4JSSwitch.doSwitch(N4JSSwitch.java:772)
	...
```
While the above code is invalid (and a validation error is already correctly shown to the user), it must be handled gracefully without any uncaught exceptions.

issues.title: N4JS Oomph Setup fails with SSL handshake_failure
issues.body:

I am using Oxygen, Eclipse IDE for Committers and the "Eclipse Projects > N4JS" project.

Right after initiating the setup, I run into a SSL handshake_failure with the update site of xpect (https://ci.eclipse.org/xpect/job/Xpect-Integration-Release/lastSuccessfulBuild/artifact/org.eclipse.xpect.releng/p2-repository/target/repository/content.xml).

Can this be reproduced on your end as well?

```

issues.title: Jump to definition / hyperlink not working in external libraries when opening file from Project Explorer
issues.body:
Hyperlinks (e.g. jump to definition with CMD+Click) are not working in source files located in the external libraries IF the file was opened by double-clicking its entry in the Project Explorer view of Eclipse. If, on the other hand, the file was opened by navigating to it via another hyperlink OR by using "Open Type", everything works as intended.

To reproduce:

1. create a new N4JS project.
2. add the following dependencies:
   ```
   "dependencies": {
   	"@n4jsd/express": "4.0.0",
   	"@n4jsd/body-parser": "1.18.3",
   	"express": "4.0.0",
   	"body-parser": "1.18.3"
   }
   ```
3. install missing dependencies.
4. create a new N4JS file with:
   ```javascript
   import BodyParser from "body-parser"
   BodyParser;
   ```
5. CMD-click on "BodyParser".
   --> In the file that was opened now, hyperlinks are working as intended.
6. close that file and reopen it using the Project Explorer view.
   --> Now, hyperlinks are NOT working.

For a possible way how to fix this, see #1122.

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-1199: Jump to definition / hyperlink not working in external libraries when opening file from Project Explorer (#1200)

* fix hyperlinks in external libraries, when opened via Project Explorer

* add a test

issues.title: "Install missing dependencies" gets confused by non-N4JS projects in workspace
issues.body:
To reproduce:

0. turn off auto build.
1. create an N4JS project using the wizard and add `"n4js-node": "0.13.1"` as dependency to the package.json file.
2. create a plain Eclipse project called `TestPlain`.
3. in the plain n4js project, add a file `package.json` with  the following contents:
   ```
   {
   	"name": "TestPlain",
   	"version": "0.0.1",
   	"dependencies": {
   		"n4js-mangelhaft-cli": "0.13.1"
   	}
   }
   ```
4. run "Install missing dependencies" (aka "big button")

You should have 18 compile errors in the external workspace.
Running "Re-register all npms" will remove those, but the 7 warnings from the shipped code won't show up!

NOTE: when creating the second project as an N4JS project and adding the same dependency, there won't be an issue!

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-1194: "Install missing dependencies" gets confused by non-N4JS projects in workspace (#1197)

* ignore projects without Xtext nature in most cases

issues.title: Some tests not executed in maven build
issues.body:
The following tests from bundle `org.eclipse.n4js.hlc.integrationtests` are not executed on Jenkins:
```
CompileAndRunTestsAllPassTest.java
CompileAndRunTestsWithFailuresTest.java
N4jscJarTesterTest.java
PerformanceReportTest.java
```
This is caused by a misconfiguration. In this bundle, only test classes with a name ending in `JarTest` or `CliTest` are being executed.

Solution: rename test classes.

Bonus: do some clean up of the tests in this bundle, e.g. change `N4jsCliTest` to not inherit from `AbstractN4jscJarTest`.

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-1188: Some tests not executed in maven build (#1189)

* rename test classes to make them be executed in maven + clean up

* change N4jsCliTest to not inherit from AbstractN4jscJarTest + clean up

issues.title: Content assist not using alias in case of existing imports
issues.body:
To reproduce:
```
import {SomeClass as SC} from "otherModule";

Some // <--
```
When doing content assist in last line after "Some" and selecting "SomeClass" from the list, the IDE replaces text "Some" by "SomeClass" which leads to an unresolved reference error. Instead, it should replace "Some" by "SC" (i.e. the alias of the existing import).

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-1183: Content assist not using alias in case of existing imports (#1184)

* refactoring: rename FQNImporter to N4JSReplacementTextApplier

* support for multi-line expectations in content assist Xpect method

* content assist uses alias of an existing import instead of element name

* add tests

* some clean up, minor improvements, more tests

issues.title: UI of external library manager in Eclipse preferences dialog not showing up
issues.body:
To reproduce:

1. start the N4JS IDE.
2. open the Eclipse preferences dialog (e.g. by pressing `CMD`+`;`).
3. go to the preference page for the external library manager (e.g. by entering "external" in the search field and then selecting "N4JS External Libraries" in the left tree).

Now the library manager UI should show up but you'll only get an empty preferences dialog:

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7124687/48006880-b19a2700-e116-11e8-8052-2aa408e7759e.png)

Note: when opening the library manager with the special button in the tool bar it is showing up normally.

* ensure library manager UI is showing up when changing preference pages

issues.title: Invalid usage of performance data collectors during clean build
issues.body:
During a clean build, the data collectors for individual validation check-methods are used without their parent collector for validations being in use. This leads to warnings on the console during clean builds when performance data collection is turned on.

NOTE: this issue is in internal functionality only used during debugging / performance testing.

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-1169: Invalid usage of performance data collectors during clean build (#1170)

* measure validations triggered via class IssuesProvider

issues.title: TimedDataCollector causing memory issues
issues.body:
Method `#consume()` in `TimedDataCollector` stores an instance of `DataPoint` for each and every measurement taken. This is causing memory issues in large builds (and thus invalidating the performance measurements).

NOTE: this code is never active in ordinary usage of the product, so this is only an issue for internal testing/debugging of the IDE.

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-1163: TimedDataCollector causing memory issues (#1164)

* disable excessive data collection

issues.title: node.js 10 warns about MAX_SAFE_INTEGER timeout
issues.body: The `keep-event` option raises a warning on node 10, that only 32bit signed integers are allowed.

commitsDetails.commitMessage: GH-1161: Use max signed 32bit int for timer value (#1162)

issues.title: Re-Indexing takes way too long after IDE crashed
issues.body:
After IDE crashed, re-indexing takes 15-20min instead of about 5min (measured on OPR). This can be reproduced:
* Crash the IDE with workspace of OPR 
* Open the IDE again and note the waiting time

Notes:
* One symptom is: each package has a small waiting time of about 500ms
* This can be cancelled. When starting maintenance action "reload libraries" or even the "big button" the same behavior might reappear.
* After performing maintenance action "delete npm folder ..." behavior goes back to normal, i.e. fast

issues.title: n4jsx emits warnings for svg elements
issues.body:
JSX allows to define svg elements. N4JSX files emit warnings for some svg elements like `circle`, `path`, `g`.

#### Generated bug report
##### foo.n4jsx.xt
```
// XPECT nowarnings --> "Tag g is an unknown HTML tag."
  <g>
  </g>

```

see https://reactjs.org/docs/dom-elements.html

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-1146: n4jsx emits warnings for svg elements (#1166)

* accept SVG tags in JSX elements

public testMeA() {
    this.orderProductStates.some(s => s.testMeA());	// s is of type OrderProductState

issues.title: Bug in string template literals sequences
issues.body:
in general escape sequences should be kept "as is" in the compiled output, e.g.
```js
`\\`, `\t` ...
```
Currently these are rewritten, replaced by tab character etc.

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-1138: Bug in string template literals sequences (#1140)

* align handling of template segments to string literals

* adjust tests + more documentation + minor clean up

* add another test

issues.title: Validation error on structural types with optional field
Trailing dot in pre-release tags of semver version constraints cause validation errors
issues.body:
Consider the dependency to `hard-source-webpack-plugin` with the version constraint of
```
^4.0.0 || ^4.0.0-beta. *|| ^3.8.1 || ^3.0.0 || ^3.0.0-rc.0 || ^2.1.0 || ^1.13.1
                     ^ ERROR
```

The dot marked causes an error in the validation (and even in the semver parser).

issues.title: Remove code indirectly copied from Java
issues.body:
Unfortunately Xtext contained some code copied from Java, which caused an IP problem:

https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=539108

Since we copied this code from Xtext, we also need to remove the affected code. Actually the Xtext IP issue was found when the N4JS code was checked, see bug report above.
There are some pull requests in the Xtext project which may help us:

https://github.com/eclipse/xtext-core/pull/870
https://github.com/eclipse/xtext-core/pull/871
https://github.com/eclipse/xtext-core/pull/872

I did a quick search (file search for "Mostly copied from") and found the following files which may need to be changed in the N4JS code

AbstractN4JSStringValueConverter.java (2 matches)
IdentifierValueConverter.java (2 matches)
N4JSStringValueConverter.java (2 matches)
RegExLiteralConverter.java
ExtensibleWizardNewProjectCreationPage.java

h2. Acceptance Criteria

- [x] Review these locations
- [x] look at the Xtext problems, try to identify more locations
- [x] fix them (maybe by using Sebastians PRs linked above).
- [x] When this issues is fixed, please report that as a comment in the CQ13482 (N4JS Initial Contribution): https://dev.eclipse.org/ipzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=13482

commitsDetails.commitMessage:

* re-implement some logic to avoid copying certain code from Xtext

issues.title: Local publishing of n4js-libs interferes with public publishing
issues.body: Local publish changes the package's version in lerna.json to 9999. This version is then used as the public version. Use `git checkout lerna.json` before public publishing.

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-1113: Local publishing of n4js-libs interferes with public publishing (#1114)

* GH-1113: git checkout

* GH-1113: Use fixed version in lerna.json

issues.title: n4js-mangelhaft marks broken dependencies as SKIPPED
issues.body: The tool sets the loader's mode to be tolerant on missing dependencies, i.e. treats it as "API not implemented". The problem is that this mechanism applies on broken dependencies or uncompiled modules, too. We should only selectively set this mode when needed per n4js runtime option.

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-1107: Loader mode for API not impl, don't set by default, exit code improvements (#1108)

*  Rename loader mode for API not impl, don't set by default
*  forward numeric exit code on errors
*  use different exit code for failed tests, to separate from compilation problems

issues.title: n4js exec doesn't wait for promise resolution for main modules
issues.body: In case a main module (with async run() method) has no pending IO, but the main promise is yet unresolved, the node process nevertheless exits.

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-1093: n4js exec doesn't wait for promise resolution on main modules (#1094)

* Add eventloop entry to avoid process exit
* simplify mangelhaft async handling and propagate proper exit code
* twisting default about keep-eventloop
* Passing keep-eventloop for test exec
* omit unresolved promises
* Ignore failed test and updateship code
* Fix failing test

issues.title: Missing validation on async function with default initializer

commitsDetails.commitMessage: #1090: Missing validation on async function with default initializer

issues.title: IndexSynchronizer does not handle the removal of shadowing runtime projects properly
issues.body:
When a runtime library projects is removed from the external library workspace (e.g. dependency to specific version is removed and "big button" is executed), the index synchroniser can run into an NPE, since it will attempt to build the project at the location of the removed project. 

Instead it needs to build the shadowed project, that now is no longer shadowed. See https://github.com/eclipse/n4js/blob/master/plugins/org.eclipse.n4js.ui/src/org/eclipse/n4js/ui/external/EclipseExternalIndexSynchronizer.java#L246.

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-1085: fix index synchronizer issues wrt. shadowed projects (#1087)

Signed-off-by: Luca Beurer-Kellner <lucabeurerkellner@gmail.com>

issues.title: A nested node_modules folder disables dependency version validation for workspace projects
issues.body:
Given a simple N4JS project with the following structure:
```
P
├── node_modules
├── package.json
├── src
│   └── A.js
└── src-gen
```

and package.json file

```
{
	"name": "P",
	"version": "0.0.1",
	"dependencies": {
		"lodash": "1.2.3"
	},
	"n4js": {
		"projectType": "library",
		"vendorId": "org.eclipse.n4js",
		"sources": {
			"source": [
				"src"
			]
		},
		"output": "src-gen"
	}
}
```

If any version of `lodash` is available (anywhere, e.g. workspace or external), the nested node_modules folder will disable version validation and allow users to request any version of `lodash`, without receiving any validation issues in their `package.json` file. This mechanism was implemented to accommodate for nested node_module folders in the external library workspace. As part of this issue, we need to make sure that the this exception does not apply for workspace projects.

**Acceptance Criteria**:
* A nested node_modules folder does not alter the behavior of version validation for workspace projects
* The custom behaviour remains active for projects in the external library workspace

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-991: A nested node_modules folder disables dependency version validation for workspace projects (#992)

Signed-off-by: Luca Beurer-Kellner <lucabeurerkellner@gmail.com>

issues.title: IDE does not allow to launch modules via 'Run with Node.js' if n4js-cli is a declared dependency of the project
issues.body:
In case `n4js-cli` is installed as external library and declared as project dependency, the IDE does no longer offer the option 'Run As > Run with Node.js` in the Run menu.

This is a bug in the computation of the required runtime libraries when determining whether a given runner can be activated or not. In case of `n4js-cli` the IDE detects a dependency cycle (via `eslint` in the devDependencies of the package) and as a consequence does not finish computing the required runtime libraries. 

**Acceptance Criteria**:
Projects that depend on `n4js-cli` can be run via the 'Run As' menu

issues.title: N4JSC.jar injection problem (Jetty port not injected, cannot run tests)
issues.body:
Currently it is not possible to run tests with N4JSC.jar :
```
42593 INFO  TesterEventBus     - Registered: org.eclipse.n4js.hlc.base.testing.LoggingTestListener@200437e8
42608 WARN  JettyManager       - Port is already in use: 9415. Trying to use next available port: 60559.
SLF4J: Failed to load class "org.slf4j.impl.StaticLoggerBinder".
SLF4J: Defaulting to no-operation (NOP) logger implementation
SLF4J: See http://www.slf4j.org/codes.html#StaticLoggerBinder for further details.
44682 INFO  JettyManager       - Jetty instance has successfully started on '60559'.
{ FetchError: request to http://localhost:-1/n4js/testing/sessions/3dd163af-704e-411f-be49-1ebe17faa9f9/start failed, reason: connect ECONNREFUSED 127.0.0.1:80
    at ClientRequest.<anonymous> (/Users/me/myproject/node_modules/node-fetch/index.js:133:11)
    at emitOne (events.js:116:13)
    at ClientRequest.emit (events.js:211:7)
    at Socket.socketErrorListener (_http_client.js:387:9)
    at emitOne (events.js:116:13)
    at Socket.emit (events.js:211:7)
    at emitErrorNT (internal/streams/destroy.js:64:8)
    at _combinedTickCallback (internal/process/next_tick.js:138:11)
    at process._tickCallback (internal/process/next_tick.js:180:9)
  name: 'FetchError',
  message: 'request to http://localhost:-1/n4js/testing/sessions/3dd163af-704e-411f-be49-1ebe17faa9f9/start failed, reason: connect ECONNREFUSED 127.0.0.1:80',
  type: 'system',
  errno: 'ECONNREFUSED',
  code: 'ECONNREFUSED' }
```

most important parts are
```
Jetty instance has successfully started on '60559'.
request to http://localhost:-1/
```

Which suggests that there is an issue with setting the port.
Value used suggests the place holder value: https://github.com/eclipse/n4js/blob/master/plugins/org.eclipse.n4js.tester/src/org/eclipse/n4js/tester/internal/DefaultTestTreeTransformer.java#L155
that should be replaced at runtime with injected value: https://github.com/eclipse/n4js/blob/master/plugins/org.eclipse.n4js.tester/src/org/eclipse/n4js/tester/internal/DefaultTestTreeTransformer.java#L51

Looks like problem with injection of testers.

issues.title: NPE when running code in IDE with runtime code installed from npm
issues.body:
Running code in IDE works only with bundled runtime code. Using runtime code in custom version provided by `npm` yields NPE exception (see stacktrace below).

Steps to reproduce

1. use wizard to create `New N4JS Project` with default greeter file
2. in generated greeter file use runtime code explicitly, e.g.  
```typescript
import {join} from "path";
console.log(join);
``` 
3. right click on a greeter file and run it -> should be no errors.
4. modify `package.json` to use runtime code from npm, e.g.: 
```typescript
{
	"name": "test",
	"version": "0.0.1",
	"n4js": {
		"projectType": "library",
		"vendorId": "org.eclipse.n4js",
		"sources": {
			"source": [
				"src"
			]
		},
		"output": "src-gen",
		"requiredRuntimeLibraries": [
			"n4js-runtime-node"
		]
	},
	"dependencies": {
		"n4js-runtime-node": "0.10.0-alpha.7aa7bbc0"
	}
}
```

6. right click greeter file to run it -> code is not executed, exception is logged internally

issues.body: When a project in the workspace depends on a runtime project in a different version than the version provided as part of the shipped code, then the "Install missing dependencies" button does not install the correct version, probably because a project of that name is already present. However, the library manager supports shadowing shipped code projects by manually installed projects.

issues.title: Make n4js-cli's build script work uniformly for both publishing and integration test
issues.body:
The n4js-cli's build script is used for both publishing and integration. During the publishing, we copy the freshly built `n4jsc.jar` from `tools/org.eclipse.n4js.hlc/target` folder to `n4js-cli/bin/` folder. However, during the integration test, `n4jsc.jar` is configured via `N4_N4JS_JAR` environment variable.

Acceptance Criteria:
* n4js-cli's build script works seamlessly in both two situations.
* It should work in CI-build/nightly-build and local integration test as well.

issues.body:

issues.title: AbstractN4JSCore.isNoValidate traverses file system
issues.body:
`org.eclipse.n4js.internal.AbstractN4JSCore.isNoValidate(URI)` traverses files system to compare given `URI` with the module filters in the manifest. Traversing file system seems obsolete for comparison itself.

While operation itself seems to not be super expensive (e.g. in one setup it takes ~15 seconds during 7 minute build of workspace) this can vary based on the machine (e.g. having SSD or not), workspace structure (large number of small files VS small number of large files) and the way it is called (multiple time for one resource by different callers).

issues.title: Library Manager does not install types for transitive dependencies
issues.body:
Assuming the N4JS project N in the workspace and N has a project dependency to A. A is an external project (i.e. an npm package) that has type definitions in the repository `n4jsd`. Regarding A, the npm itself is installed using `npm -install` and the types are installed by the library manager.

A problem arises when project A is depending on B which also has type definitions. B will be installed by npm, but its type definitions will not be installed by the library manager.

issues.title: 'Install npm package to workspace' does not work for broken external library projects (only on second try)
issues.body:
Given an external workspace that contains a broken external library project (e.g. cannot parse manifest), our 'Install npm package to workspace' quick fix does currently not do what it advertises. On a first run, it will actually uninstall the package in question and only on the second try the quick fix will have the desired effects.

**Steps to Reproduce**:

1. Open a fresh workspace and create some dummy project `A`
2. In the manifest, declare `fetch-mock` as dependency
3. Use the quick fix to install it
4. Close the IDE
5. Navigate to the `fetch-mock` in the hidden `node_modules` folder of the workspace (`.metadata/.plugins/org.eclipse.n4js.external.libraries/.n4npm/node_modules/fetch-mock/`)
6. Break the `manifest.n4mf` file by editing and introducing a syntax error (e.g. add an additional comma somewhere)
7. Relaunch the IDE using the workspace. Since the `fetch-mock` package is now broken, the IDE will report it missing in the manifest of `A`
8. Perform the `Install npm pacakge to workspace` quick fix on the `fetch-mock` dependency. This will print the following on the npm console:
```
[28-05-2018 09:55:31] Installing NPM(s): fetch-mock
removed 8 packages in 0.605s
```
The log suggests that npm is actually removing said dependency. The `fetch-mock` dependency is still reported missing.

9. Run the `Install npm package to workspace` quick fix it a second time. The npm console will now display something like:
```
[28-05-2018 09:57:02] Installing NPM(s): fetch-mock
(...)
+ fetch-mock@6.4.2
added 8 packages in 1.572s
[28-05-2018 09:57:09] External libraries built: fetch-mock
[28-05-2018 09:57:09] Workspace projects affected: A
```

After this second try, the `fetch-mock` dependency can be resolved correctly.

**Proposed Acceptance Criteria**:

* On the first try the quick fix performs the appropriate actions to fix the missing dependency issue (re-install it)

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-848: 'Install npm package to workspace' does not work for broken external library projects (only on second try) (#864)

* fix to correctly install after uninstall an external library

* add check to avoid modification of broken manifest

* move error detection to make tests work

issues.title: Split error messages in manifest file regaring missing module specifier
issues.body:
The error with the message "Module specifier ** does not exist." appears:
- at the MainModule attribute
- at the noModuleWrap entry in the manifest.

The latter one should be a warning. Reason: if the given specifier does not exist, an error is raised. However: if source locations are given that do not exist, only a warning is issued. This is inconsistent and should be adjusted.

issues.title: Tests run in debug verbose mode producing unnecessary logs
issues.body:
Currently a lot of HLC tests run in `--debug --verbose` mode which produces large log without any value. 
We can use those switches locally when test fails, or in branch when we debug issues, but running them on every branch is waste.

issues.title: Dialog for installing external dependencies is using thread locking which hangs sometimes
issues.body:
In the dialog that coordinates setting up dependencies for the workspace, thread suspending and notification was used to synchronise UI and other threads carrying out operations.

In case of unexpected issues, this was causing zombie threads and UI windows hanging, which was causing havoc in build system in the SWTBot tests.

Synchronisation has to be carried in other way, to avoid hanging windows.

commitsDetails.commitMessage:

* replace dialog with wizard

issues.title: Catch the case when the last argument passed to n4jsc.jar is not a valid list of files
issues.body:
In `N4JScBase` class, we parse the last multi-valued parameter into a list of `java.io.File`, if the list of strings are not valid and of type SOMETHING, the `List<File> srcFiles` is still parsed into a list of type `List<File>` but the files do not exist. Of course, everything else will fail completely from there.

```
@Argument(multiValued = true, usage = "filename of source (or project, see -bt) to compile")
List<File> srcFiles = new ArrayList<>();
```
# AC

- Invalid cases of `srcFiles` are caught and an error is displayed.

issues.title: In manifest files the property 'noValidation' does not work when the source property is "."
Duplicate projects are not handled in N4JSC
issues.body:
When user invokes N4JSC with multiple project locations, it may happen that those locations contain multiple projects with the same `ProjectID`. Depending on the order in which locations will be traversed, this might cause builds to fail, even if two projects with the same ID are essentially to identical copies of the same project. 
Additionally if those two projects are different (but have same ID) only one of them will be processed, which again will result in build failure.

Same as in IDE case, the N4JSC does not support compiling multiple projects with the same ID. 
N4JSC needs to handle invalid user input.

(Note, this was discovered after switching  Eclipse Oxygen and Xtext 2.13 but seems unrelated to those two directly. Quite possibly internally order in which some build info has changed, which exposed issue in  the N4JSC).

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-780 N4JSC should handle projects with the same project ID (#782)

* add fail fast in the headless compiler for projects with duplicated ID
* adjust duplicates detection to ignore same project passed multiple times
* resolve symlinks used in the headless compiler
* add test

issues.title: Incremental builder unnecessarily builds many files after changing white-space in N4JS file
issues.body:
To reproduce: requires internal code base.

This is caused by property `astMD5` in EMF entity `TModule`, which causes the serialized TModule inside a ResourceDescription to change whenever this MD5 hash changes. And despite its name, this hash is not derived from the AST but from the source code, see `N4JSASTUtils#md5Hex(XtextResource)`.

Minor: also rename user data key "serializedScript" to "serializedTModule" (to avoid confusion in the future).

issues.title: Make @Singletons singletons (again)
issues.body:
**Bug**
The bug is that we have multiple instances of @Singleton classes.

**Solution**
The solution is to write a test that checks runtime behaviour and detects those multiple singleton instances.

**Description**
The N4JS project suffers from multiple instances of classes annotated with @Singleton. This happens because the Xtext framework uses multiple injectors which all have their own scopes. The provided means by Xtext to solve this is the shared injector. However, it is unknown whether there are multiple instances of a singleton since there is no runtime check. Hence, this situation leads often to the situation of having multiple instances of a singleton with is very cumbersome to identify as a cause of some other (unrelated?) problem.

issues.title: Code formatter introduces compilation error in generic default parameters
issues.body:
Code formatter changes `f1a` to `f1b` which is compilation error in N4JS.
```typescript
function f1a(data : Array<Object> =){}
function f1b(data : Array<Object>=){} //error
```

Note that using square bracket notation is working in both cases
```typescript
function f2a(data : [Object] =){}
function f2b(data : [Object]=){}
```

AC:

- code formatter does not change `> =` to `>=`
- or we make `>=` compilable

issues.title: HLC test with external dependency is unstable
issues.body:
in hotfix 3661aa732fee90aa0af08c1906e9187a1d06a70a test that was failing in some build runs was adjusted to pass in most cases.
Still in some setup test fails, i.e. it behaves like before hotfix. 
Issue seems to be with external library that reexports APIs of its transitive dependencies. That creates impression of non-deterministic behavior since it is hard to control all contributing factors.

Test in question should have its assertions relaxed:
 - we want to assert that installation of  external libraries succeeds,
 - we want to assert that we can execute code from external library,
 - we are **not** interested in asserting details of the external library API

issues.title: Quick Fix for "node_modules folder and N4JS index are out of sync" does not handle cancellation correctly (InterruptedException)
issues.body:
When the application of the quick-fix for issue "node_modules folder and N4JS index are out of sync" is cancelled using the 'Cancel' button of its progress monitor, exceptions are thrown on the console.

**Suspected Reason**
The implementation of the Quick Fix does not consider its cancellation via the progress monitor.

**Reproduce**

1. Provoke inconsistent N4JS index state so that the issue appears as a marker in the Problems View
2. In the Problems View, select "Quick Fix" from the context menu of such a marker
3. In the appearing dialog select the corresponding Quick Fix "Synchronize N4JS index to node_modules folder" at press "Finish"
4. Immediately cancel the appearing Progress Dialog using 'Cancel'

* aligned code to existing code in code base

* adjust new lines in to string

issues.title: use precise version in runtime environment
Editing a location file removes it from search results in find references
issues.body:
To reproduce

1. Create class `A` in `A.n4js`
2. Create class `B` in `B.n4js`, make `B` extend `A`
3. Search for references of `A`
4. Assert when `B.n4js` is in the search results 
5. Edit `B.n4js`, e.g. add/edit a comment and save.
6. `B.n4js` is **removed** from search results 

Expected behaviour (either):
a) search results are updated with correct information (e.g. `B.n4js` is removed if user removes all references, file `C.n4js` is added to the result when user adds reference)
b) search results do not get updated with edits, and user has to re-run search to get new results.

Note that in JDT behaviour `a` is implemented (but does not have this buggy behaviour).


![screencast 2018-04-11 16-36-26](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/944287/38624225-e29cfa52-3da7-11e8-983c-f28b30448a63.gif)

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-724: Editing a location file removes it from search results in find references (#752)

This PR use Guice overriding module to provide a customized ReferenceSearchResultContentProvider that deactivates removal of search result when a resource is changed.

issues.title: Revisit Promise signatures
issues.body:
(moved here from https://github.com/NumberFour/n4js/issues/25, aka IDEBUG-342; original reporter: @dbo )

Currently Promise has some flaws, e.g.

- The following should rather use an Iterable (see http://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-262/6.0/#sec-promise.all):
  ```ts
  public static all(iterable: Array<?>): Promise<Array<any>, any>
  public static race(iterable: Array<?>): Promise<?, any>
  ```

- Promise.all cannot cleanly resolve to some type, I suggest to change it to
  ```ts
  public static <T> Promise<Array<T>, any> all(Array<union{Promise<T, ?>, T}> iterable)
  ```
- The error type F is rather inconvenient and is commonly set to any/? (e.g. `@Async` notation).
Recommendation is that the error type is always of type Error (see https://www.w3.org/2001/tag/doc/promises-guide#reasons-should-be-errors).
WebIDL doesn't type it at all (any, see https://heycam.github.io/webidl/#es-promise).

It is only about changing the signature, cf.  https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html#sec-promise.all

issues.title: Quickfix "Add import" and Organize Imports working incorrect when @@StaticPolyfillModule is present / not on top
issues.body:
Given the polyfilling class below
```ts
@@StaticPolyfillModule
@StaticPolyfill
export public class PolyfillAwareClass extends PolyfillAwareClass {
	libFoo : LibraryFoo;	
             ^^^^^^^^^^
}
```
**Error message**
> Couldn't resolve reference to Type 'LibraryFoo'.

The provided quickfix "Import LibraryFoo" will add the following import
```ts
import {LibraryFoo} from "LibraryFoo";
```
above the annotation `@@StaticPolyfillModule`, which will result in an error.

Also, when now applying Organize Imports, the added import will be removed again.

**Problems**
* Quickfix does not respect annotation  `@@StaticPolyfillModule`
* Organize imports also does not respect  `@@StaticPolyfillModule`

issues.title: Static polyfill not working with type parameters having recursive upper bounds
issues.body:
A (probably) bogus error is showing up when tryping to define a static polyfill for a class that has type parameters with recursive upper bounds.

Filled module:

```ts
@@StaticPolyfillAware

export public class ToBeFilled<T,S extends T> {}
```

Filling module:

```ts
@@StaticPolyfillModule

@StaticPolyfill
export public class ToBeFilled<T,S extends T> extends ToBeFilled<T,S> {} // error: "S is not a subtype of T." at "S"
```

copied from https://github.com/NumberFour/n4js/issues/205

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-578/GH-585: Static polyfill not working with type parameters having recursive upper bounds (#625)

* fix scoping of upper/lower bound of type parameters of polyfills

* add a test

issues.title: Recursion not possible for a type argument of a generic class in a static polyfill
issues.body:
The description is a mouthful but here is an example.

The generated class:

``` typescript
@@StaticPolyfillAware
export public class AClass<T extends AnInterface<T>> extends BClass<T> { ... }
```

The static polyfill:

``` typescript
@StaticPolyfill
// XPECT FIXME noerrors -->
export public class AClass<T extends AnInterface<T>> extends AClass<T> { ... }`
```

There is an error at the `AClass<T>` saying: `T is not a subtype of AnInterface<T>.` Without recursion, no problem occurs (cf. [the static polyfill for Quantity](https://github.numberfour.eu/NumberFour/stdlib_api/blob/master/packages/eu.numberfour.stdlib.model.common.api/src/n4js/n4/model/common/Quantity.n4jsd#L17)).


copied from https://github.com/NumberFour/n4js/issues/274

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-578/GH-585: Static polyfill not working with type parameters having recursive upper bounds (#625)

* fix scoping of upper/lower bound of type parameters of polyfills

* add a test

issues.title: Validate project manifest in headless compiler
issues.body:
Currently, the headless compilers does not validate the manifest files. It should validate them before it starts actually compiling projects.

* Should all manifests be validated, or only those of the projects which the user explicitly requested to be compiled? In other words, should manifests of dependencies also be validated?
* Manifests should be validated before the actual compilation begins, that is, [during project registration with the file based workspace](https://github.com/NumberFour/n4js/blob/master/plugins/eu.numberfour.n4js.generator.headless/src/eu/numberfour/n4js/generator/headless/N4HeadlessCompiler.java#L492).

copied from https://github.com/NumberFour/n4js/issues/337

issues.title: Runtime errors when user instantiates N4BuiltInClasses
issues.body:
there are runtime exceptions when user tries to initiate N4BuiltInClasses:
```typescript
//executes with no error
console.log(new N4Object())
console.log(new N4Enum())

//each throws TypeError
console.log(new N4Annotation())
console.log(new N4EnumType())
console.log(new N4Accessor())
console.log(new N4DataField())
console.log(new N4Method())
console.log(new N4Interface())
console.log(new N4Role())
console.log(new N4Class())
```

moved from https://github.com/NumberFour/n4js/issues/19

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-505: Runtime errors when user instantiates N4BuiltInClasses (#661)

* adjust declarations of built-in types used for reflection

* fix some problems unrelated to the current task

* add tests for other reflection-related built-in classes

* remove obsolete built-in type N4Field

* disallow instantiating/extending N4Enum, N4StringBasedEnum

* minor fix

* update runtime code to recent changes in builtin_n4.n4ts

* update shipped code

* fix some tests

* fix some out-dated information + add some additional info in spec

* let reflection-related built-in types inherit from N4Object

* fix more tests

issues.title: IDE needs to gracefully handle invalid paths defined in manifest

commitsDetails.commitMessage: GH-504 check if location segments are valid (#514)

issues.title: Optional parameter or assignment without space before equals results in an error

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-491: Optional parameter or assignment without space before equals results in an error (#895)

* formatter also formats initializers in formal parameters

* adjusted grammer N4JS.text to support f(a : A<T>=null)

issues.title: Return types of FunctionExpressions are incorrect when based on a nested function call's return type

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-490: Return types of FunctionExpressions are incorrect when based on a nested function call's return type (#522)

* fix problem in handling of single-expression arrow functions

* some refactoring for simplification

* some clean up

* fix a problem revealed by tests

* fix another problem revealed by tests

* review feedback

issues.title: Give better error message if NPM installation fails due to invalid package main module path
issues.body:
To reproduce, try to install package 'http'.
![log4](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/944287/35334812-dadb7d6e-0113-11e8-8ee5-8a622e54d842.png)

moved from https://github.com/NumberFour/n4js/issues/341

commitsDetails.commitMessage: GH-489 handle missing main module in less verbose manner (#511)

issues.title: String based enum with literal `default` does not validate.

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
GH-487: String based enum with literal `default` does not validate. (#517)

* align syntax for names of enum literals to members of classifiers

* remove special handling of enum literals in TokenTypeRewriter

* remove special handling of enum literals in TokenTypeRewriter (part 2)

issues.title: Transpiler error when compiling expression with stray boolean operator
issues.body:
The following code causes the transpiler to run into a severe error.

```javascript
function m() {
	let valid = true && true &&
	return valid;
}
```

Note the stray boolean AND operator at the end of the boolean expression. If that is removed, all is well.

Problem view says

> Severe error occurred while transpiling module A. Check error log for details about the failure.

issues.title: Wrong directory structure after NPM package adaptation
issues.body:
Some NPMs have a directory structure such as

```
/package.json
/dist/this.js
/dist/that.js
...
```

Note that the .js files are inside a directory called `dist` here. During the adaptation process, the N4JSD files should be put alongside the .js files into the dist directory, which is currently accomplished correctly if the following two conditions are met:

- The main module is set in the NPM package.json (see `NpmPackageToProjectAdapter#computeMainModule).
- The directory structure of the N4JSD project is

```
/<version>/.project
/<version>/manifest.n4mf
/<version>/manifest.fragment
/src/this.n4jsd
/src/that.n4jsd
```

Note that the `src` folder does not reflect the structure of the NPM package, that is, there is no `dist` folder inside it. But to facilitate the shadowing necessary to edit the N4JSD project inside the workspace, and for reasons of coherence, the directory structure inside the `src` folder should reflect the directory structure inside the NPM package, i.e., it should be

```
/<version>/.project
/<version>/manifest.n4mf
/<version>/manifest.fragment
/src/dist/this.n4jsd
/src/dist/that.n4jsd
```

But in that case, the n4jsd files are put into the wrong place after adaptation has taken place. This is because the adaptation process takes the main module directive into account when computing the target path for the n4jsd files.

To allow the correct directory structure in the N4JSD project, the adaptation process should not evaluate the main module directive and just merge the contents of the `src` folder into the NPM package.

issues.title: Exception in JSXBackendHelper in case project "react" exists in workspace
issues.body:
If `react` is installed and managed inside the library manager (as an external library) everything works fine; but if in addition to that `react` is imported into the Eclipse workspace, then an exception is thrown in class `JSXBackendHelper`.

To reproduce:
1. create a simple N4JS project with a simple n4jsx file using a JSX tag.
2. create an N4JS project with the below manifest and an `index.n4jsd` in source folder `src`.
3. perform a clean build -> exception should be thrown.

Manifest to use:
```
ProjectId: react
ProjectType: library
ProjectVersion: 16.2.0
VendorId: npm
Output: "."
MainModule: "index"
ModuleLoader: commonjs
Sources {
    source {
        "src"
    }
}
```

issues.title: Cannot assign undefined in a typed destructuring pattern
issues.body:
**Code snipped**
```javascript
// XPECT noerrors -->
let [a : int, b : int] = [undefined, 0]; // error here

let c : int = undefined; // works
```

**Error message**
`Variable a cannot hold destructured value at index 0: any is not a subtype of int.`

**Note**
Typing a destructuring pattern is only possible like shown below. It is not supported to use a syntax that Typescript uses: `let [a, b] : Array<int>`.

issues.title: duplicated libraries in library manage cause unresolved references in projects
issues.body:
Duplicated libraries in library manage cause unresolved references in projects.
For example, assume project with dependency to `n4js.lang`, i.e. project using `N4Injector`
Next add to that project some npm dependency that depends on `n4js.lang`.
Installing main dependency with library manager causes npm to install `n4js.lang`.
Now library manager sees two copies of `n4js.lang`:
 1. first one that comes with ide
 2. second one installed via npm

This will cause unresolved references to the `N4Injector`

issues.title: Improve automatically added import for React
issues.body:
To reproduce: create an N4JS project with a project dependency to React and add the following code to an `n4js` or `n4jsx` file:
```
let e: Element<undefined>;
```
Now let the IDE add the missing import (does not matter if organize imports or content assist is used). This will produce the following import:
```
import {Element} from "index";
```
While valid, this import is misleading and might be ambiguous if there are other projects with a module "index" on top level.

Change functionality to produce an import as such:
```
import {Element} from "react";
```

Note: the solution should not be specific to react but should work for all projects with a "main module" defined in the manifest (i.e. the logic should be something like: "when importing the main module, use a project import, if possible").

issues.title: N4JSResource#loadFromDescription() should not change state of resource in case of failure
issues.body:
In method `N4JSResource#loadFromDescription()`, the state of the resource is changed even if loading from index failed (for example, because no information was available in the index). In this case, an AST proxy is added to the contents list but no TModule is being added. This can cause issues in builds that run on a broken index (i.e. partially filled index).

Try changing the above method such that when loading from description / the index fails, the receiving resource will remain unchanged.

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
#362: N4JSResource#loadFromDescription() should not change state of resource in case of failure (#363)

* 362: do not change state of resource if #loadFromDescription() fails

* 362: adjust one & remove two out-dated tests

Two test cases were removed for the following reasons:
1) they used excessive mocking and therefore did not test the actual
code & behavior. For example, #testLoadReplacesTypeInformation() tested
that a TModule is proxified during demand-loading from source after
loading from index, but this behavior has been changed for a while (now
reconciliation is used) and the test was still green because it mocked
so much,
2) they relied on an undocumented and unspecified resource load state
(after a failed call to #loadFromDescription()),
3) some expectations were out-dated (e.g. the proxification of the
TModule during demand loading),
4) those aspects of the tests that are still valid are covered by the
newer test class N4JSResourceLoadStatesTest (with less mocking).

issues.title: Clean up Xpect tests in bundle org.eclipse.n4js.n4jsx.xpect.ui.tests
issues.body:
Execution of many (or all) tests in bundle `org.eclipse.n4js.n4jsx.xpect.ui.tests` seems to be broken. If the test expectation is changed to some non-sense value, the tests remain green. Also, many tests have invalid code and/or manifests and should thus be red anyway.

To reproduce:
Change the expectation of the scoping tests in `SimpleComponentDescriptions.n4jsx.xt` to some non-sense value and run the test. Test will still be green.

1. make sure tests are executed correctly.
2. clean up all tests in this bundle to ensure (1) all code / manifests are valid and (2) all tests and test expectations make sense.

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
#355: Clean up Xpect tests in bundle org.eclipse.n4js.n4jsx.xpect.ui.tests (#356)

* 355: repair & clean up tests in org.eclipse.n4js.n4jsx.xpect.ui.tests

* 355: remove some debug code

* 355: handle IEObjectDescriptionWithError in predicate of Xpect scope

* 355: remove some changes only used for experimentation/debugging

* 355: fix & improve another test in another bundle

* 355: avoid some problems due to having Xpect in the product

Since Xpect is also installed in the product, all files that contain the
string "XPECT", case sensitive, are handled by Xpect in special ways
(file extension does not matter). This can lead to problems during
PluginUI tests and therefore this PR is changing some tests to not use
the problematic substring in project names.

issues.title: Remove HeadlessCompilerFactory
issues.body:
Class `HeadlessCompilerFactory` is used to create an instance of `N4HeadlessCompiler` for testing. However, this is by-passing the dependency injection setup in `N4jscBase#initInjection()` and is using some ad hoc setup instead. This means the tests are not testing the proper DI setup and and whenever the proper setup changes, the `HeadlessCompilerFactory` would have to be adjusted (but that never happened).

Another problem is that this is blocking required changes in the proper DI setup in `N4jscBase#initInjection()`.

Thus, remove `HeadlessCompilerFactory` and use `N4jscBase#doMain()` instead.

issues.title: Headless compiler does not support external libraries in N4JSX files
issues.body:
Acceptance criteria:
- Headless compiler supports external libraries in N4JSX files

commitsDetails.commitMessage:
#349: Headless compiler does not support external libraries in N4JSX files (#352)

* 349: another work-around for the multi-language problem

In the headless builder, the known "multi-language problem" (IDE-2493)
caused imports from external NPM dependencies to fail in N4JSX files.
This commit applies a work-around for this particular issue, but the
general problem needs to be fixed in IDE-2493.

* 349: fix incorrect copyright year

issues.title: ClassCastException in PrevStateAwareDirtyStateManager
issues.body:
To reproduce:
1. create a new N4JS project,
2. open the auto-created manifest,

issues.title: Graceful handling of missing "react" dependency for N4JSX
issues.body:
The error case of an `.n4jsx` file located in an N4JS project that does not declare "react" as a project dependency (in the manifest.n4mf) must be handled gracefully. To reproduce: create a new N4JS project, add a file `R.n4jsx` with the code ```javascript let elem =
; elem; ``` and observe the exceptions thrown. For example: ``` Caused by: java.lang.RuntimeException: Compiler cannot locate JSX backend to use for this resource at org.eclipse.n4js.n4jsx.transpiler.utils.JSXBackendHelper.lambda$1(JSXBackendHelper.java:163) at java.util.Optional.orElseThrow(Optional.java:290) at org.eclipse.n4js.n4jsx.transpiler.utils.JSXBackendHelper.getAnyBackend(JSXBackendHelper.java:163) at org.eclipse.n4js.n4jsx.transpiler.utils.JSXBackendHelper.jsxBackendModuleQualifiedName(JSXBackendHelper.java:148) at org.eclipse.n4js.transpiler.es.transform.SanitizeImportsTransformation.patchJSX(SanitizeImportsTransformation.java:120) at org.eclipse.n4js.transpiler.es.transform.SanitizeImportsTransformation.transform(SanitizeImportsTransformation.java:88) at org.eclipse.n4js.transpiler.AbstractTranspiler.transform(AbstractTranspiler.java:207) at org.eclipse.n4js.transpiler.AbstractTranspiler.transpile(AbstractTranspiler.java:147) at org.eclipse.n4js.transpiler.es.EcmaScriptTranspiler.transpile(EcmaScriptTranspiler.java:159) at org.eclipse.n4js.transpiler.es.EcmaScriptSubGenerator.internalDoGenerate(EcmaScriptSubGenerator.java:151) at org.eclipse.n4js.generator.common.AbstractSubGenerator.doGenerate(AbstractSubGenerator.java:126) ... 39 more ``` Also consider other ways of provoking this, e.g. by commenting out the "react" dependency in a manifest, etc. ACs: 1. make sure all code can cope with this error case (no arbitrary exceptions must be thrown), 2. show an error message at an appropriate location (probably just one per project would be ideal, but maybe one message per `.n4jsx` file would also be ok), 3. ensure that all transitions are properly supported (i.e. all ways of entering and leaving this error case must correctly trigger to the necessary updates in the IDE).

issues.title: NullPointerException in AbstractSubGenerator#doGenerate()
issues.body:
If an exception is thrown during transpilation, the `AbstractSubGenerator` may run into (another) exception due to a null pointer. This second exception will then hide the original exception, making debugging of the root problem impossible.

Change code to avoid the second exception (always a NullPointerException).

issues.title: Avoid exceptions when querying OSGI during build
issues.body:
In the Eclipse implementation, when the application is shutting down, a build can be triggered. 

Currently, we are querying OSGI 
for generator/transpiler class during a build. This should be changed because it could happen that we are querying information that is not there anymore when the application is shutting down. 

One way to reproduce a bug due to this is as follows:
- Open N4JS IDE with OPR
- Clean build OPR. In the middle of the build, cancel the build
- Close N4JS IDE

In the console log
```
!MESSAGE org.eclipse.n4js.generator.SubGeneratorType  - org.eclipse.n4js.transpiler.es.EcmaScriptSubGenerator cannot be found.

66759 [Worker-5] WARN  org.eclipse.n4js.generator.SubGeneratorType  - org.eclipse.n4js.transpiler.es.EcmaScriptSubGenerator cannot be found.

issues.title: Runners and testers are registered twice in the N4JSC.jar
issues.body:
For the non-OSGI N4JSC.jar it was required to register runners and testers manually. After switching to OSGI version, double invocation throws exceptions (see below).

Notice that registers for runners and testers are much more restrictive in this behaviour, than file extension registers, that simply accept all values.

Since OSGI/non-OSGI setup for N4JSC.jar has not been finalised yet, make forced registers in N4JSC.jar conditional to the mode in which it is running.

issues.title: Avoid early proxy resolution in types builder
issues.body: The types builder is triggering EMF proxy resolution in some places, which is disallowed. Search for `already created` in source code of types builder to find these places.

commitsDetails.commitMessage: #267: avoid early proxy resolution in types builder (#268)

issues.title: Avoid locking UI thread due to hover and hyperlink navigation (in editor)
issues.body:
When the user is hovering (to show a tool tip) or navigating hyperlinks (i.e. hovering over a navigable element while holding down Ctrl / CMD) the default code in

* `DefaultHyperlinkDetector#detectHyperlinks(ITextViewer, IRegion, boolean)`
* `AbstractEObjectHover#getHoverRegion(ITextViewer, int)`

will invoke `XtextDocument#readOnly(IUnitOfWork<T, XtextResource>)` which will wait until a read-lock is available, meaning the UI thread will be blocked during that time.

ACs:

1. avoid locking the UI thread in these cases.
2. consider showing the tooltip / hyperlink later, once the read-lock can be acquired OR at least provide some feedback to the user about why tooltip / hyperlink is unavailable (carefully consider what's the best solution from a usability perspective).

issues.title: I18l issue with date
issues.body:
duplicated definition file for date causes validation / compilation problems. The `Date.n4js` is in both 
 * n4js-runtime-es2015
 * n4js-runtime-ecma402

using only one library causes compilation issues in code, using both causes validation error in the manifest.

Remove `Date.n4js` from `n4js-runtime-es2015`.
Ensure proper visibility of types in `n4js-runtime-ecma402`

issues.title: Types builder fails to account for the callable constructors when relinking types
issues.body:
We get index out of bound in the types builder when types in definition files have callable constructor.

This leads to exceptions at runtime, e.g. in hover for the type information (see below).

## reproduce
Setup:
1.  create `TT.n4jsd` with content
```typescript
/** TT t t */
export external public class TT {
	():Object

	m1() 
	m2() 
	m3() 
	m4() 


	f1;
	f2;
	f3;
}
```
2. create `Test.n4js` file with following content
```typescript
import * as ns from "TT";
console.log(ns.TT)
```

Test:
1. open `Test.n4js` in new editor (important to have fresh editor)
2. hover over `ns.TT`

When running from eclipse console shows errors:

```
1 [Text Viewer Hover Presenter] ERROR org.eclipse.xtext.ui.editor.hover.html.DefaultEObjectHoverProvider  - Error on computation of hover information. No hover information available for org.eclipse.n4js.ts.types.impl.TFunctionImpl@6b4453cd (name: Router) (exportedName: Router) (declaredTypeAccessModifier: public, declaredProvidedByRuntime: false) (external: true, returnValueMarkedOptional: false, declaredAsync: false, declaredGenerator: false, constructor: false) at offset: 58, length: 6

issues.title: Add intl. parameters to Number.toLocaleString
issues.body:
Number.toLocaleString is defined in the ECMAScript spec as follows:

```
Number.prototype.toLocaleString ( [ reserved1 [ , reserved2 ] ] )
```

The parameters are defined in the i18n API (ECMA-402):
https://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-402/4.0/index.html#sup-number.prototype.tolocalestring

```
Number.prototype.toLocaleString ( [ locales [ , options ] ] )
```

For details about these parameters, see https://www.ecma-international.org/ecma-402/4.0/index.html#numberformat-objects

We shoud update our signature of that method to
```
toLocaleString(locales=: string, options=: ~Object with {..})
```

(or add a helper type for the options)

issues.title: FQN are supported in type references
issues.body:
Currently in type references it is possible to use FQN to refer to non global type without any imports.

Assuming module Mod1.n4js with content
```typescript
export public var A :string = "Mod1.A";
```
in module Mod2.n4js it is possible to refer to `A` with FQN like:
```typescript
let a : Mod1.A;
```

Type references to `A` should be allowed only with import:
```typescript
import {A} from "Mod1"
let a : Mod1.A;
```
or with the namespace import
```typescript
import * as namespace from "Mod1"
let a : namespace.A;
```

Notice that using namespace with name as the module only looks like the original example:
```typescript
import * as namespace from "Mod1"
let a : Mod1.A;
```
but this is actually different in a way that import is required and the type ref is not fqn but namespace access.

issues.title: ASTStructureValidator must not resolve proxies
issues.body:
The `ASTStructureValidator` runs even before the types builder, so it is not allowed to resolve EMF proxies, in particular it must not resolve Xtext's lazy-linking proxies.

However, at the moment it is doing that. For example `model.label` in the following line:
https://github.com/eclipse/n4js/blob/master/plugins/org.eclipse.n4js/src/org/eclipse/n4js/validation/ASTStructureValidator.xtend#L1218

AC:
1. change `ASTStructureValidator` to not resolve proxies.
2. ~consider adding fail-fast assertions to ensure proxy resolution does not take place before types builder has completed.~ (moved to #219)

issues.title: IDE is sometimes slow when many editors with large files are open
Project Location Working Sets aren't handling late RepositoryCache/Workspace updates
issues.body:
The Project Location Working Set Manager depends on the RepositoryCache in that it infers the dynamically created Working Sets in parts from the repositories the projects are contained in. This should be fixed as it was done for Git Working Sets in https://github.com/eclipse/n4js/pull/189. 

Apart from that, this Working Set Manager also fails to adapt to other workspace changes like the creation of a new project / removal of a project / import of new projects.

For instance when creating a new project, the manager fails to create a new Working Set for it (if necessary) and doesn't show the new project in the project explorer. This happens even when the expectation would be, that it adds it to an existing working set.

issues.title: N4JS Project wizard can't handle existing project at same location
issues.body:
Steps to reproduce:  

1. Create a new N4JS project
2. Create a new N4JS Class in the project or modify the greeter file 
3. Delete the project but make sure not to select 'Delete project contents on disk (cannot be undone)' 
4. Create a project with the same name 

The second project creation will yield in multiple exceptions on the console although the project creation seems to be successful.   

What actually happens, is that the IDE fails to create resources (`manifest.n4mf`, greeter N4JS-file) that already exist at the same location.   

JDT, in comparison, handles this more gracefully by informing the user about the collision: 

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17903049/29417199-a7e31404-8368-11e7-870c-bc75b981ba1a.png)  

All other options of the wizard are disabled, since everything will be configured based on the existing sources. 

I propose similar behaviour for the N4JS IDE.

issues.title: Check handling of cancel indicator in type resolution
issues.body:
Investigating #66 and some test problems (https://github.com/eclipse/n4js/blob/master/tests/org.eclipse.n4js.ui.tests/src/org/eclipse/n4js/dirtystate/CanLoadFromDescriptionPluginUITest.xtend#L275) @mor-n4  and I figured that there are inconsistencies how cancellation is propagated during type resolution.

Multiple things that need to be double checked:
- Is the cancel indicator properly propagated when resource boundaries are crossed during type resolution?
- Do we use OperationCanceledManager.checkCanceled(CancelIndicator) rather than isCancelled?
- Do we catch OperationCanceledError or OperationCanceledException by accident rather than OperationCanceledManager.propagateIfCancelException(Throwable)?
- Do we pass on the correct cancel indicator, e.g. in the editor context?

issues.title: Issues with resolving structural type reference in the function casts
issues.body:
There is an issue with proper handling of structural type references when casting to a function type.

Behavior showed below happens when casting to a function type whose **return type or parameter type** is a structural one (including all versions `~`, `~~`, `~r~`, `~i~`... etc.). 

##### Step 1
Start with a new project  with a class `A` in its own module, and some other module which tries to cast anything to a function with structural type in the signature (e.g. `{function( ~r~A): any}`). Since there is no import, there is an error marker in the editor on the reference, an error in the problems view, an error in the package explorer
![step1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/944287/29357262-32f78144-8277-11e7-9b5e-1775f919b00d.png)


 ##### Step 2
**Manually** add import and save. All error markers are removed. 
Notice invalid `warning` marker is added for the import.
![step2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/944287/29357340-6fd0fffa-8277-11e7-83d7-6258410f6cdd.png)

##### Step 3
**Manually** remove import and save. All warning markers are removed.
`error` markers for unresolved reference are added, to the problem view and to the package explorer. Editor **does not contain error marker**, but notice artifact on the sidebar of the editor, 
typical for error markers that exist, but were removed/invalidated by some IDE internals.
![step3](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/944287/29357413-c02bc944-8277-11e7-864c-bcdc8e4c4016.png)

##### Step 4
Add small modification to the file, that can later be processed by the code formatter, and save.
Notice artifact in the editor sidebar is gone and editor does not shoe any `error`s.
![step4](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/944287/29357552-3ddb4fae-8278-11e7-978f-bf5f291c65fc.png)

##### Step 5
Invoke code formatter to format the code and save. Notice error markers reappear in the editor.
![step5](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/944287/29357604-6de37e9c-8278-11e7-863e-8350e216c6b0.png)

##### Step 6
Invoke quick fix on the broken reference. Import  is proposed. Notice **type and its module** are properly found.
![step6](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/944287/29357754-eaeebabe-8278-11e7-94ea-da76e92a8d39.png)

##### Step 7 
Select proposed import and save. Import was added, errors are gone. **Import is marked as unused.**
![step7](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/944287/29357822-32304afa-8279-11e7-9c9e-94b97d836510.png)

##### Step 8
Invoke organize imports. New import is proposed, but it is broken proposal - **module for** `A` **is not resolved**.
![step8](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/944287/29357868-64422ab8-8279-11e7-8663-9fb111acef40.png)

##### Step 9
Proceed with organize imports wizard and save afterwards. 
Notice: 
 - valid warning that was marked as unused is removed.
 - new import, that is invalid was added. 
 - error marked on type function cast is removed (except artifact in the sidebar)
 - broken import just adds more errors to the module.
![step9](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/944287/29357997-d9c362ac-8279-11e7-89ae-7bc6ae185d89.png)

issues.title: Eclipse-launched N4JS IDE crashes on large and fast text output
issues.body:
When launching a N4JS IDE using an Developer Eclipse instance (e.g. via Run Configuration N4JS_IDE) on macOS, it is easy to cause a total crash of the IDE by executing the following N4JS file:

```
while(1) { console.log("Line"); }
```

The output of this script causes large and quick text output in the console which crashes the IDE.

I suspect the cause of this issue to be related to crashes the team has experiencing over the last few weeks, when deleting all of the editor content. 

The console output of such a crash looks like this:

```
#
# A fatal error has been detected by the Java Runtime Environment:
#
#  SIGSEGV (0xb) at pc=0x00007fffdd983050, pid=3825, tid=0x0000000000000307
#
# JRE version: Java(TM) SE Runtime Environment (8.0_131-b11) (build 1.8.0_131-b11)
# Java VM: Java HotSpot(TM) 64-Bit Server VM (25.131-b11 mixed mode bsd-amd64 compressed oops)
# Problematic frame:
# C  [libsystem_platform.dylib+0x2050]  _platform_memmove$VARIANT$Nehalem+0x70
#
# Failed to write core dump. Core dumps have been disabled. To enable core dumping, try "ulimit -c unlimited" before starting Java again
#
# An error report file with more information is saved as:
# (...)/Eclipse.app/Contents/MacOS/hs_err_pid3825.log
#
# If you would like to submit a bug report, please visit:
#   http://bugreport.java.com/bugreport/crash.jsp
# The crash happened outside the Java Virtual Machine in native code.
# See problematic frame for where to report the bug.
#
```

This happens only when launching the IDE out of an Developer Eclipse instance. This does not happen to downloaded binary versions of the IDE. For now this is only known to happen on macOS.

issues.title: TModule must be correctly rewired when AST is loaded after TModule
issues.body:
When a TModule is loaded from index, and after that the AST is resolved (via astElement),
the module loaded from the index must be correctly rewired. At the moment, a new TModule is created and the old TModule becomes inconsistent.

issues.title: Outline view sometimes shows *null* instead of inherited members
issues.body:
This is a follow up of #99. The outline sometimes shows "*null*" instead of the inherited members.

As already noted in #99, at the moment the AST is accessed via the type model. This is not only a performance issue (which is not that problematic in case of the outline view). Since we still have a problem of correctly loading the AST after the type model (in that case, the type model becomes invalid), a work-around for the outline is to avoid accessing the AST if possible.

Actually, it is possible to not access the AST for super types at all. This is a valid work-around for the describe bug.
